text: I think we can all agree The Greatest
Story Ever Told was that of an Italian
plumber who eats magic mushrooms while
jumping on glomas and dodging THS to
save a princess from a turtle dinosaur
Nintendo's software development team is
awesome but Nintendo's legal team is
terrifying I actually tried to name my
firstborn son Luigi and immediately got
served a seasoned assist so I had to
name him snake instead today the Seal
Team Six of legal teams has their sight
set on an open source project called
Yuzu it is February 28th 2024 and you're
watching the code report people steal
and reupload my content all the time I
could do something about it and make a
Digital Millennium Copyright Act report
but that would take an hour out of my
day so instead I just bend over and take
it Nintendo on the other hand will not
be bent over they have a long history of
defending their intellectual property
rights through legal action back in the
9s there used to be this thing called
The Game Genie which allowed you to
modify Nintendo games to cheat with
things like invincibility the thing sold
millions of units but Nintendo sued
galoo toys arguing that they were
violated because it modified their
copyrighted Works Nintendo lost that
lawsuit Mission failed we'll get them
next time however Nintendo doesn't
always lose if you have a Raspberry Pi
laying around one thing you definitely
shouldn't do is go to Retro p.org dok
and download this tool that turns your
Raspberry Pi into an arcade with
emulators for NES Super Nintendo and
Nintendo 64 retropi itself is not
illegal but if you go to websites like
emulator games.net you can download ROM
images which are digital copies of video
games these websit still exists but a
few years back when Nintendo released
its mini retro throwback console their
legal team went after r hosting websites
and this one dude who is making 30k a
year from ROM Universe has been ordered
by the court to pay 2.1 million to
Nintendo in Damages to be paid in $50
monthly installments and the guy's
already defaulted on the first payment
Nintendo doesn't need the money but they
want to ruin this guy's life to send a
message that Nintendo will not be bent
over and that brings us to 2024 and the
Yuzu emulator lawsuit Yuzu is an open-
Source Nintendo switch emulator that you
can find on GitHub it's written in C++
and allows you to run Nintendo switch
games on Windows Linux and Android it
Curr has 34,000 stars but be careful not
to click this button because you might
get sued Yuzu also has a patreon that's
bringing in 30k a month that's a nice
amount of money but they're going to
need a lot more than that to fight their
legal battle with Nintendo where they're
accused of quote facilitating piracy at
a colossal scale and because Yuzu is
actually making money it helps justify
Nintendo's case to go on the offensive
let's take a look at how Yuzu works so
you can decide who's in the wrong here
first you go to yu- u.org to download
the installer you then configure the
settings for your hardware and now
you're ready to start playing digital
versions of Nintendo switch games well
actually it's not quite that simple
you'll also need a hackable Nintendo
switch here's where the legal gray area
comes in for some games to run you need
to dump system files from a real
Nintendo switch and in the documentation
it explains how to do this by exploiting
older switch consoles that are
vulnerable to the Fus galet exploit
which is a cold boot attack that
exploits a flaw in the Nvidia Tegra X1
processor used in the switch the exploit
runs before the bootloader allowing you
to change anything in the existing
switch OS this allows hackers to run
custom firmware and Homebrew
applications on the switch and because
it's on the processor itself Nintendo
can't fix this with a simple software
update and that means most units made
before mid 2018 are vulnerable to this
exploit now switch games are also
encrypted to prevent piracy but Yuzu can
dynamically decrypt them at runtime and
Nintendo is arguing that that violates
dmca which clearly states that you can't
circumvent software protections what's
interesting though is that the actual
encryption keys don't come from Yuzu
they need to come from the end user so
technically Yuzu is not providing
pirated games just the tools to actually
run them and it's typically legal to
reverse engineer something and emulate
it as long as you're not breaking
digital Rights Management there's
another Nintendo emulator out there
called dolphin that runs GameCube in Wii
games it was going to be released on
Steam but then they put the kabash on
that after Nintendo filed a dmca
complaint in that case though dolphin
contained an AES 128 encryption key used
to encrypt wi games in its source code
and that gave Nintendo a much stronger
argument that dolphin was actively
circumventing digital Rights Management
Nintendo never actually sued dolphin
though they only got them deplatform
from Steam with Yu though you need to
bring your own Keys which makes
Nintendo's case a lot weaker because
again there's a lot of legal precedent
that protects emulators it's illegal to
Pirate software but that's not what Yuzu
is doing it's merely giving you a gun
with the emulator and teaching you how
to make bullets in the quick start guide
and really there's nothing wrong with
that unless you use that information to
go postal or God forbid pirate a
Nintendo switch game this has been the
code report thanks for watching and I
will see you in the next one
